title: How can we know if we've reached our happiness? - Quora
tags: Life Advice for People in Their 20s

response.answer_text: Thanks for the A2A. What helps me is remembering that happiness is not a destination, it's a byproduct of other things. Take another example like 'good health'. Being healthy is a byproduct of laughing, walking, fresh air, enjoying food, having good friends and spending time with them. Do all these things and good health will probably follow. But set 'good health' as a goal and you are always worrying and measuring and being a trial to your friends about what you can and can't eat. You become a bit of a crank. I think happiness is the same. If you pursue kindness, friendship, exercise, work you can lose yourself in and treating others well then one day you will notice you are happy. But pursue happiness and you risk spending a lot of time unhappy with your lot. And since happiness is partially a mood it will also come and go, just like our other moods. Realising this is a large part to becoming happier. But wanting to throw a switch which turns happiness on permanently will, ironically, only make you less happy. Treat yourself well, treat others well, enjoy what you've been given and happiness will be along soon enough.

Thank you for the A to A. Another great thought provoking question. My answer is that you can only individually answer that question for one's self. Personally, I do not know of anyone that has stated they have "reached" their happiness. I do believe most want to be happy, and make others happy as well. I do believe I feel happy everyday, sad everyday, scared everyday, etc.. since you made me think of it. Looking back, as just an observation, I believe little things have made me happier than big things in life. Happiness, for me has not ever been a "constant" state. I want it to be though, so I will follow this question on Quora. I am not sure it can be a constant when change occurs every millisecond that marches by.

The most difficult thing for a person is to know himself or herself. I know this because once a few decades ago I tried to analyze myself few times and always failed to do so. I have given up and have felt much better ever since. The question that I asked myself is - Who am I? I will probably live for 85 yrs, and that is a speck of time compared to the billions and billions of years of this universe. Just after this speck of time, that was given to me, I am just a pinch of dust. So basically, today too, I consider myself a pinch of dust. So what is happiness or sadness for this pinch of dust? Accept life as it comes, let life lead you, and we as a human being have the responsibility to live life to the fullest at that moment of time.

It should be peace which you are looking out for. Happiness is not permanent and will come and go and stay a bit or awhile. Peace is the one which will stay. Peace is attained when you are identify yourself with your self. Right now you identity yourself with people, things, events, culture and religion etc. Read this book: Beyond Happiness, Finding and Fulfilling Your Deepest Desires by Dr. Frank J. Kinslow. You will know what I am talking about. Best Wishes

when you stop looking for anything and get totally intoxicated with life within you, there you are. You don't have to go to anybody, drop all the philosophies and ideologies and at last when you are totally empty, you yourself will dissolve. Thats the peak of possibility of being human where you will experience everything as one.
Happiness isn't something you reach... its something that happens to you. Be grateful first.

True, permanent “happiness” is Bliss, which only comes on the attainment of Enlightenment. There is no mistaking it. The Bliss is overwhelming and all-satisfying. You will have tastes of it as you evolve. Nothing external to yourself can ever produce happiness that lasts, as the relative world is constantly changing and undependable. Meditate and stay with it.
It's a cliche, but I think the journey TO happiness is the biggest part of it. And happiness is largely what YOU define it as being.

This question speaks to happiness as being a destination. It is a road to travel by, not a destination point. So, only you can know when you are truly happy. Hopefully you will have many moments that are happy along the way to your destination.
If you doubt if you are happy, you are not.when you are happy you just know it and enjoy it, not doubts.
Each evening when I get back home after an honest day's work, and see my family's glowing/sparkling  eyes , I know I've 'plucked' happiness.
It depends on what happiness means to you! :)
